title: Cruel thug is jailed for 14 months for knocking out a vulnerable disabled man
text:
A cruel thug has been jailed for beating a disabled man to the ground - after taunting him saying: 'Just one punch.'

Burly Hefin Parker, 22, floored his vulnerable victim in an attack in Ammanford, South Wales, filmed by a laughing friend.

Ellis Kelman, 19, uploaded the footage to social media - but both men were reported to the police when the video was shared hundreds of time.

The footage showed Parker encouraging his victim to hit him in the cheek before telling him to put his 'hands down' and punching him to the head.

Parker swung a hard punch at the man which sent him crashing to the floor.

Mobile phone footage shows Parker who said: 'Go on, just one punch. Just one punch. Hands down. Hands down. One punch. I'll give you twenty.'

The footage showed Parker encouraging his vulnerable victim to hit him in the cheek before telling him to put his 'hands down' and punching him to the head in an attack at a bus stop in Ammanford, South Wales, filmed by a laughing friend

Parker, of Ammanford, admitted actual bodily harm and was jailed for 14 months at Swansea Crown Court. Kelman of Llangennech, leaded guilty to encouraging/assisting in the commission of an assault. He was handed a suspended sentence and ordered to carry out 100 hours of unpaid work

The horror attack took place at a bus stop in Ammanford on July 2 and was shared hundreds of times online.

A court heard Parker was arrested later that day and Kelman attended a voluntary interview the following day.

Parker, of Ammanford, admitted actual bodily harm and was jailed for 14 months at Swansea Crown Court.

Kelman of Llangennech, leaded guilty to encouraging/assisting in the commission of an assault.

He was handed a suspended sentence and ordered to carry out 100 hours of unpaid work.

Ellis Kelman, 19, uploaded the footage to social media and both men were reported to the police when the video was shared hundreds of time

Speaking after the sentence Temporary Detective Sergeant Rebecca Thomas said: 'To have carried out such an attack for no apparent reason on a vulnerable member of our community was totally unacceptable.

'I am comforted by the fact that so many members of our local community picked up the phone to make us aware of this incident and the video they had seen on social media. I thank each and every person who got in touch. This allowed police officers to take swift action and made this court result possible.'
description: Hefin Parker, 22, floored his disabled victim at a bus stop in Ammanford, South Wales. He was jailed for 14 months at Swansea Crown Court.
